chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In his letters, the Apostle frequently discusses this calling, but he's never clearer and more concise than in his letter to the Romans, where he outlines four stages of divine blessings.

For those whom He foreknew, He also predestined to be conformed to the image of His Son, so that He might be the firstborn among many brothers. And those He predestined, He also called; those He called, He also justified; and those He justified, He also glorified. Romans eight.

The first blessing is predestination, where we are preordained to eternal life. The second is the calling, which invites and inspires us to seek eternal life. The third is justification, where our sins are forgiven and we earn eternal life by doing good works. The fourth is glorification, when righteousness turns into judgment and we possess peace and eternal life.

The first happens with Him, not within us; the second comes from Him within us; the third comes from Him, with our cooperation; the fourth comes from Him, after we have already earned it.

First, He chooses us before we exist; second, He advises us to be good; third, He makes us just; fourth, He makes us glorious and immortal.

The first is the divine truth of foreknowledge; the second is the infusion of grace; the third is the operation of justice; the fourth is the reward of glory.

First, He foreknows those who will exist long after; second, He calls the undeserving; third, He forgives sins and grants merits; fourth, He crowns those who have done well endlessly.

Just as none are glorified unless justified, nor justified unless called, so none are called unless predestined. This special calling of God is attributed to Him alone; by it, only those are called who will become saints, as the Apostle says, they were called to be saints according to His purpose. Not according to their own merit, but according to God's purpose, because the gifts and calling of God are irrevocable. Romans eleven.
chunks.original_latin:
Per totum corpus Epistolarum suarum de hac vocatione
Apostolus saepenumero loquitur, nusquam
tamen evidentius et brevius quam paulo ante ad
Romanos, ubi quatuor divinorum beneficiorum gradus
ita complectitur. Nam quos praescivit et praedestinavit
conformes fieri imaginis Filii sui, ut sit
ipse primogenitus in multis fratribus. Quos autem
praedestinavit, hos et vocavit; et quos vocavit, hos
et justificavit; quos autem justificavit, illos et glorificavit
(Rom VIII). Vides quia primum erga nos
 Dei beneficium est praedestinatio, qua nos ad vitam
praeordinamur aeternam; secundum, vocatio qua
invitamur et inspiramur ut vitam appetamus aeternam;
tertium, justificatio, qua peccatis remissis, vitam
bene operando meremur aeternam; quartum, glorificatio,
quando justitia conversa in judicium, pacem
et vitam possidemus aeternam. Primum quidem
apud ipsum fit, non in nobis; secundum ab ipso in
nobis; tertium ab ipso, cooperantibus nobis;
quartum ab ipso, jam emeritis nobis. Primum nos
eligit antequam simus; secundum, admonet ut boni
simus; tertium, efficit ut justi simus; quartum, ut
gloriosi et immortales simus. Primum nihil est aliud
quam divinae veritas praescientiae; secundum, infusio
gratiae; tertium, operatio justitiae; quartum, retributio
 gloriae. Primum, praenoscit longe post futuros;
secundum, vocat immeritos; tertium, peccata remittens,
merita donat; quartum, jam bene meritos
sine fine coronat. Sicut igitur non glorificantur nisi
justificati, nec justificantur nisi vocati, sic procul
dubio non vocantur nisi praedestinati. Haec est illa
specialis vocatio Dei quae nulli attribuitur nisi ei;
qua non vocantur nisi qui futuri sunt sancti, qui
juxta Apostolum (Rom VIII), secundum propositum
vocati sunt sancti. Non quidem secundum meritum
suum, sed secundum propositum 351 Dei, quia
sine poenitentia sunt dona et vocatio Dei (Rom XI).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Although the Book of Genesis doesn't specifically state that Adam was given this calling, it doesn't prevent us from interpreting it that way. It also doesn't exclude him from salvation; in fact, its words seem to suggest his salvation.
chunks.original_latin:
Quod si hac vocatione vocatum fuisse Adam liber
Geneseos aperte non dicit, posse tamen intelligi non
 interdicit, nec illum a salute contendit excludere,
cum potius verba ejus saluti illius videantur alludere.
